chapter.htmlHeader: How should I diagnose chronic sinusitis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Diagnose chronic rhinosinusitis if there are characteristic symptoms in addition to objective evidence of sinonasal inflammation on examination.

  • In adults:
    • Diagnostic symptoms of chronic sinusitis are the presence of nasal blockage (obstruction/congestion) or nasal discharge (anterior/posterior nasal drip) with facial pain/pressure (or headache) and/or reduction (or loss) of the sense of smell, lasting for longer than 12 weeks without complete resolution. 
  • In children:
    • Diagnostic symptoms of chronic sinusitis are the presence of nasal blockage (obstruction/congestion) or nasal discharge (anterior/posterior nasal drip) with facial pain/pressure and/or cough (daytime and night-time), lasting for longer than 12 weeks.
  • Detect evidence of sinonasal inflammation by:
    • Inspecting and palpating the maxillofacial area to elicit swelling or tenderness.
    • Performing anterior rhinoscopy (using the largest speculum of an otoscope, or a head light and nasal speculum) to identify:
      • Signs which support a diagnosis of chronic sinusitis such as nasal inflammation, mucosal oedema, and mucopurulent nasal discharge.
      • Associated pathology such as nasal polyps, or anatomical abnormalities such as septal deviation. 
  • Assess for predisposing factors to chronic sinusitis, such as:
    • Allergic rhinitis (symptoms include sneezing; watery nasal discharge; nasal itching; and itchy, watery eyes).
    • Asthma.
    • Immunosuppression.
  • Do not routinely request radiological imaging in primary care.
  • If signs and symptoms are not typical of chronic sinusitis and the diagnosis is in doubt, refer to an ear, nose and throat specialist to rule out an alternative diagnosis.
    • Urgent referral for further investigation is required if there are unilateral symptoms, epistaxis, blood-stained discharge, crusting, orbital symptoms (such as diplopia or reduced visual acuity), or neurological symptoms or signs.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Diagnosis

  • Information on the diagnostic symptoms of chronic sinusitis is based on expert opinion published in the European position paper on rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps [Fokkens et al, 2012]. The recommendations for adults also reflect a UK commissioning guide published by ENT UK and the Royal College of Surgeons [ENT UK and Royal College of Surgeons, 2016].
  • The recommendation on examination is extrapolated from a number of sources: expert opinion published in the European position paper on rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps [Fokkens et al, 2012], a summary of Canadian guidelines and expert opinion on chronic sinusitis [Kaplan, 2013; Sedaghat, 2017], and a UK commissioning guide on chronic sinusitis from ENT UK and the Royal College of Surgeons [ENT UK and Royal College of Surgeons, 2016]. 
  • In addition, a US guideline on adult sinusitis emphasises the importance of the presence of signs and symptoms of chronic sinusitis in addition to documented sinonasal inflammation (polyps, oedema, or purulent mucus) to increase diagnostic accuracy. The authors suggested examination ideally with an endoscope or headlight and nasal speculum, but noted that an otoscope is often used in primary care, although the sensitivity is reduced compared with the other methods [Rosenfeld et al, 2015]. For children, a US clinical consensus statement on paediatric chronic rhinosinustis also included signs of mucosal oedema, purulent drainage, or polyps in their clinical definition of chronic rhinosinusitis [Brietzke et al, 2014].

Assessment for risk factors

  • Assessing for predisposing factors to chronic sinusitis is based on expert opinion in a UK commissioning guide published by ENT UK and the Royal College of Surgeons [ENT UK and Royal College of Surgeons, 2016] and US guidelines on adult sinusitis [Peters et al, 2014; Rosenfeld et al, 2015]. These factors are listed as contributing or exacerbating factors for chronic sinusitis in Canadian and US guidelines covering adult and paediatric populations and an international consensus statement [Kaplan, 2013; Brietzke et al, 2014; Orlandi et al, 2016]. 

Radiological imaging in primary care

  • Experts contributing to a UK commissioning guide are of the opinion that the usefulness of plain X-ray is limited for the diagnosis of chronic sinusitis because it underestimates bony and soft tissue pathology [ENT UK and Royal College of Surgeons, 2016]. This is consistent with US expert opinion questioning its accuracy for evaluation of the paranasal sinuses [Sedaghat, 2017].  
  • CT is not recommended by ENT UK and the Royal College of Surgeons for primary care use because it is usually reserved for people selected for surgical interventions to minimise the risk of radiation exposure [ENT UK and Royal College of Surgeons, 2016].   

Considering an alternative diagnosis

  • The recommendation to consider an alternative diagnosis if there are symptoms atypical of uncomplicated sinusitis reflects expert opinion in a UK commissioning guide on chronic sinusitis which lists symptoms for which an urgent (2 week) referral should be considered [ENT UK and Royal College of Surgeons, 2016]. It may also be necessary for a specialist to request a CT scan or perform endoscopy to confirm the person has chronic sinusitis with or without nasal polyps because symptoms may overlap with those of perennial rhinitis [Kaplan, 2013; Peters et al, 2014].
